repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Similarly to `nvim_get_keymap()`, expose `callback` for commands backed by a lua function

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/fafc329bbd1e15f9ab595568e8cd8b10295113dd/src/nvim/mapping.c#L2105-L2107

comment_data.body: Doesn't `nvim_create_user_command` call this `preview`? Should always use the same names for input/output if possible. Ideally, they should be "roundtrippable", but even if not..

can test `preview`/ `complete` in here too?

```suggestion
  it('gets callbacks defined as Lua functions', function()
```

It certainly does, I would've named it `preview` but we already have that above:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/c628918b4da9b48154732d0dce379a43c2a64de8/src/nvim/usercmd.c#L1790-L1794

We've two options I think:
1. Keep this as `preview_callback` (not clobbering the old API)
2. `preview` at the moment is `true`/`false` so we tweak that so it'll be `<lua func>`/`nil`, which will obviously retain the same truthy/falsiness

I prefer the latter, would you agree? (gone with this approach for the [below comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36415#discussion_r2544420524) but happy to revert)

That seems like a mistake , not obvious from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/46536f53e82967dcac8d030ee3394cdb156f9603 if there was an explicit reason why a boolean is returned. cc @famiu 

I think we should just change it. It's a bug fix, I doubt anyone is depending on the current boolean result.

I was going to ask what is the behavior when called via RPC. It looks like the API automatically omits the Lua function results, correct?

Actually, all of these cases were `preview=false`, so maybe this test needs a tweak to confirm what happens in the "truthy" case. (I.e. define a `preview` function, and perhaps also a string command if that is not already tested.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -160,7 +154,6 @@ describe('nvim_get_commands', function()
       definition = 'call \128\253R4_just_great()',
       name = 'Cmd4',
       nargs = '0',
-      preview = false,

comment_data.body:
> It looks like the API automatically omits the Lua function results, correct?

<details><summary>Yes, I believe you're right</summary>

Server:
```sh
$ nvim -u NONE --listen 0.0.0.0:6666
```

Client:
```sh
$ vim --server 0.0.0.0:6666 --remote-expr 'nvim_get_commands({}).Open' | cat -v
table: 0x01046d19c0^[[?1049h...
```
so `Open` is a command, we get its definition as a table (and the vim UI was disappearing before I could see anything, hence `cat -v` and the escape codes)

I know `Open` has a lua callback and when sent via RPC:
```sh
$ nvim --server 0.0.0.0:6666 --remote-expr 'nvim_get_commands({}).Open.callback' | cat -v
vim.NIL^[[?1049h...
```

We get `nil`, so all good
</details>

---

> maybe this test needs a tweak to confirm what happens in the "truthy" case

Done (a2456f3257739d64eb21cd), confirmed that the `'customlist'` string is tested too
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -160,7 +154,6 @@ describe('nvim_get_commands', function()
       definition = 'call \128\253R4_just_great()',
       name = 'Cmd4',
       nargs = '0',
-      preview = false,

comment_data.body:
> That seems like a mistake , not obvious from [46536f5](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/46536f53e82967dcac8d030ee3394cdb156f9603) if there was an explicit reason why a boolean is returned. cc @famiu
> 
> I think we should just change it. It's a bug fix, I doubt anyone is depending on the current boolean result.

IIRC it was returned to indicate if a command supported command preview or not, but if we just return the callback then it's unnecessary as they can just check if it's nil

comment_regular_data.body:
I've broken something memory wise:

```
:=vim.api.nvim_get_commands{}
E5108: Lua: string length overflow
```

and:
```
:echo nvim_get_commands({})
```
yields a segfault:
```
  * frame #0: 0xADDR libsystem_platform.dylib`_platform_memmove + 492
    frame #1: 0xADDR nvim`ga_concat_len(gap=0xADDR, s="<garbage>", len=52093473040) at garray.c:193:3
    frame #2: 0xADDR nvim`decode_string(s="<garbage>", len=52093473040, force_blob=false, s_allocated=false) at decode.c:272:7
    frame #3: 0xADDR nvim`object_to_vim_take_luaref(obj=0xADDR, tv=0xADDR, take_luaref=true, err=0xADDR) at converter.c:307:11
    frame #4: 0xADDR nvim`object_to_vim_take_luaref(obj=0xADDR, tv=0xADDR, take_luaref=true, err=0xADDR) at converter.c:333:7
    frame #5: 0xADDR nvim`object_to_vim_take_luaref(obj=0xADDR, tv=0xADDR, take_luaref=true, err=0xADDR) at converter.c:333:7
    frame #6: 0xADDR nvim`api_wrapper(argvars=0xADDR, rettv=0xADDR, fptr=EvalFuncData @ 0xADDR) at funcs.c:368:3
    frame #7: 0xADDR nvim`call_internal_func(fname="nvim_get_commands", argcount=1, argvars=0xADDR, rettv=0xADDR) at funcs.c:281:3
    frame #8: 0xADDR nvim`call_func(funcname="nvim_get_commands", len=17, rettv=0xADDR, argcount_in=1, argvars_in=0xADDR, funcexe=0xADDR) at userfunc.c:1774:15
    frame #9: 0xADDR nvim`get_func_tv(name="nvim_get_commands", len=17, rettv=0xADDR, arg=0xADDR, evalarg=0xADDR, funcexe=0xADDR) at userfunc.c:580:11
```

We end up thinking an object is a string, in `object_to_vim_take_luaref()`:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/8e5d397764975ece4e4297f0c54be6085b2891ff/src/nvim/api/private/converter.c#L305-L309

but on inspecting it, I'm fairly sure it's a luaref that's been corrupted and we should be in that case of the `switch`.

Any tips on what I've done wrong?

ASAN:
```
=================================================================
==2370644==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow on address 0x7dec01c06100 at pc 0x55b33d1277fd bp 0x7ffc3b7dbdd0 sp 0x7ffc3b7db590
WRITE of size 48 at 0x7dec01c06100 thread T0
    #0 0x55b33d1277fc in __asan_memcpy (**/build/bin/nvim+0xd917fc) (BuildId: 221f30914a7fc36d6b87714a92a0e99327465f69)
    #1 0x55b33e5f9396 in commands_array **/src/nvim/usercmd.c:1846:5
    #2 0x55b33d1c928f in nvim_buf_get_commands **/src/nvim/api/command.c:1299:12
    #3 0x55b33d1c9068 in nvim_get_commands **/src/nvim/api/command.c:1275:10
    #4 0x55b33db77952 in nlua_api_nvim_get_commands **/build/src/nvim/auto/lua_api_c_bindings.generated.h:2037:38
    #5 0x55b33e922c95 in lj_BC_FUNCC (**/build/bin/nvim+0x258cc95) (BuildId: 221f30914a7fc36d6b87714a92a0e99327465f69)
    #6 0x55b33e90ccd9 in lua_pcall **/.deps/build/src/luajit/src/lj_api.c:1151:12
    #7 0x55b33dbcc919 in nlua_pcall **/src/nvim/lua/executor.c:179:16
    #8 0x55b33dbd1ac4 in nlua_typval_exec **/src/nvim/lua/executor.c:1490:7
    #9 0x55b33dbd4e4a in ex_lua **/src/nvim/lua/executor.c:1730:3
    #10 0x55b33d8f974d in ex_equal **/src/nvim/ex_docmd.c:6259:5
    #11 0x55b33d8b1ddf in execute_cmd0 **/src/nvim/ex_docmd.c:1762:7
    #12 0x55b33d895595 in do_one_cmd **/src/nvim/ex_docmd.c:2392:7
    #13 0x55b33d88ab56 in do_cmdline **/src/nvim/ex_docmd.c:679:20
    #14 0x55b33deac4d2 in nv_colon **/src/nvim/normal.c:3197:18
    #15 0x55b33de998bc in normal_execute **/src/nvim/normal.c:1253:3
    #16 0x55b33e3b2f13 in state_enter **/src/nvim/state.c:100:26
    #17 0x55b33de7c654 in normal_enter **/src/nvim/normal.c:523:3
    #18 0x55b33dbfcfb0 in main **/src/nvim/main.c:656:3
    #19 0x7fdc02227674 in __libc_start_call_main /usr/src/debug/glibc/glibc/csu/../sysdeps/nptl/libc_start_call_main.h:58:16
    #20 0x7fdc02227728 in __libc_start_main /usr/src/debug/glibc/glibc/csu/../csu/libc-start.c:360:3
    #21 0x55b33d028004 in _start (**/build/bin/nvim+0xc92004) (BuildId: 221f30914a7fc36d6b87714a92a0e99327465f69)

0x7dec01c06100 is located 0 bytes after 4096-byte region [0x7dec01c05100,0x7dec01c06100)
allocated by thread T0 here:
    #0 0x55b33d12bb05 in malloc (**/build/bin/nvim+0xd95b05) (BuildId: 221f30914a7fc36d6b87714a92a0e99327465f69)
    #1 0x55b33dd9aa24 in try_malloc **/src/nvim/memory.c:113:15
    #2 0x55b33dd9ac84 in xmalloc **/src/nvim/memory.c:147:15
    #3 0x55b33dd9d72d in alloc_block **/src/nvim/memory.c:717:12
    #4 0x55b33dd9d7d9 in arena_alloc_block **/src/nvim/memory.c:724:20
    #5 0x55b33dd9e0de in arena_alloc **/src/nvim/memory.c:768:7
    #6 0x55b33d2d5f53 in arena_dict **/src/nvim/api/private/helpers.c:520:3
    #7 0x55b33e5f6524 in commands_array **/src/nvim/usercmd.c:1780:14
    #8 0x55b33d1c928f in nvim_buf_get_commands **/src/nvim/api/command.c:1299:12
    #9 0x55b33d1c9068 in nvim_get_commands **/src/nvim/api/command.c:1275:10
    #10 0x55b33db77952 in nlua_api_nvim_get_commands **/build/src/nvim/auto/lua_api_c_bindings.generated.h:2037:38
    #11 0x55b33e922c95 in lj_BC_FUNCC (**/build/bin/nvim+0x258cc95) (BuildId: 221f30914a7fc36d6b87714a92a0e99327465f69)

SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow (**/build/bin/nvim+0xd917fc) (BuildId: 221f30914a7fc36d6b87714a92a0e99327465f69) in __asan_memcpy
Shadow bytes around the buggy address:
  0x7dec01c05e80: 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
  0x7dec01c05f00: 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
  0x7dec01c05f80: 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
  0x7dec01c06000: 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
  0x7dec01c06080: 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
=>0x7dec01c06100:[fa]fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa
  0x7dec01c06180: fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa
  0x7dec01c06200: fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa
  0x7dec01c06280: fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa
  0x7dec01c06300: fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa
  0x7dec01c06380: fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa fa
Shadow byte legend (one shadow byte represents 8 application bytes):
  Addressable:           00
  Partially addressable: 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 
  Heap left redzone:       fa
  Freed heap region:       fd
  Stack left redzone:      f1
  Stack mid redzone:       f2
  Stack right redzone:     f3
  Stack after return:      f5
  Stack use after scope:   f8
  Global redzone:          f9
  Global init order:       f6
  Poisoned by user:        f7
  Container overflow:      fc
  Array cookie:            ac
  Intra object redzone:    bb
  ASan internal:           fe
  Left alloca redzone:     ca
  Right alloca redzone:    cb
==2370644==ABORTING
```
You need to increase the arena size:
```diff
diff --git a/src/nvim/usercmd.c b/src/nvim/usercmd.c
index 3ff9bde322..38c8c75352 100644
--- a/src/nvim/usercmd.c
+++ b/src/nvim/usercmd.c
@@ -1777,7 +1777,7 @@ Dict commands_array(buf_T *buf, Arena *arena)
   Dict rv = arena_dict(arena, (size_t)gap->ga_len);
   for (int i = 0; i < gap->ga_len; i++) {
     char arg[2] = { 0, 0 };
-    Dict d = arena_dict(arena, 14);
+    Dict d = arena_dict(arena, 15);
     ucmd_T *cmd = USER_CMD_GA(gap, i);
 
     PUT_C(d, "name", CSTR_AS_OBJ(cmd->uc_name));
```

Ah doh, yes that was rather silly of me. Fixed

I've also added `preview_callback` and changed `complete` so it's the actual function instead of `"<Lua function>"`. I appreciate this is a break in the API though, so we could add an extra member for the complete function, if that's preferable.

Also, happy to move the new changes into a different part of news.txt if desired

Looks like seven test jobs failed due to 503s / compute tokens running out, that other [test failure](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/19546260842/job/55965716250?pr=36415) looks to be unrelated:

<details><summary>Test output</summary>

> ```
> FAILED   test/functional/ui/cmdline2_spec.lua @ 59: cmdline2 block mode
> ./test/functional/ui/cmdline2_spec.lua:61: Row 13 did not match.
> Expected:
>   |                                                     |

>   |*{16::}  ^                                                  |
> Actual:
>   |                                                     |
>   |{1:~                                                    }|
>   |{1:~                                                    }|

>   |{1:~                                                    }|

>   |*:  ^                                                  |
> 
> To print the expect() call that would assert the current screen state, use
> screen:snapshot_util(). In case of non-deterministic failures, use
> screen:redraw_debug() to show all intermediate screen states.
> 
> Snapshot:
> screen:expect([[
>                                                        |
>   {1:~                                                    }|*11
>   :if 1                                                |
>   :  ^                                                  |
> ]])
> 
> stack traceback:
> 	./test/functional/ui/screen.lua:906: in function '_wait'
> 	./test/functional/ui/screen.lua:536: in function 'expect'
> 	./test/functional/ui/cmdline2_spec.lua:61: in function <./test/functional/ui/cmdline2_spec.lua:59>
> ```

</details>

title: feat: add (lua) callback to `nvim_get_commands()`
